Unnamed Space Idle combines the addictive nature of idle games with a thrilling sci-fi twist, as you fight to save humanity from waves of alien invaders. The game lets you customize your ship with different weapons and defenses to counter specific enemy types, adding a layer of strategy to the usual idle progression. With its long-form progression and strategic depth, it's the perfect blend of casual gameplay and meaningful customization for fans of sci-fi and idle games alike.

negative.review: Starts off with decent progression but as more features unlock, the balance breaks. All the game ends up being is finding which combination of upgrades will allow you to increase one stat the most, and then resetting each time you want to max a different stat, You HAVE to select extremely specific upgrades, crew, void devices, etc. to have any chance to progress. The problem is that each upgrade multiplies a stat by 10x-100x and the game requires that you hit certain breakpoints to be able to progress, meaning you basically have to get everything exact or you are simply wasting your time.

As far as idle games go, this one was pretty good at the start.  It has expanded over time with new achievements and game systems, but none of them have improved the enjoyment of the game.  It's just become a considerably longer, more grindy, idle game.  Can't recommend unless you are looking for something you can log into daily for the next several years to clear... if there isn't another patch.

Personally, I got a little overwhelmed with the complexity of certain aspects by the 5th area. I feel like there is too much faffing about to be enjoyable, even for an idle game. I prefer my games very simple, without too many separate upgrade functions. But it might suit those who enjoy that sort of thing. It's just not for me.

Upon learning a little more about the game from other reviews, it seems to be intended that you need to build your ship(s) a specific way to progress past certain points. That also doesn't appeal to me. I just like to wing it and leave things running until I get bored and uninstall.

Still, if that's your vibe then you'll love this.

Let me preface by saying this: I understand why people like this idler and I can see why it appeals to a lot of people. However, it is simply not my style so I can't recommend it.

In general, the structure of this idler is quite solid. The systems are introduced well (albeit too early in my opinion for some cases since the milestones are too close to each other) and they have great synergy. There is a ton of complexity for people who want to min-max this game and it's easy to experiment with how the systems work together. The monetisation is also not predatory. You mostly buy AI points (which you can earn through achievements as well) and skins. AI points are helpful but not mandatory (you can buy the mandatory upgrades with what you earn for free and still have plenty to spare). It also has a good offline system and the UI/graphics is nice and easy to understand. It's also still getting constant updates so props to the developer for that although I feel like it's quite solid already at its current state.

My gripes with it is that progress is quite slow. You hit wall after wall constantly. This is both a good thing and a bad thing. It's good because this is a great opportunity for puzzle solving and experimentation. It's bad because if you're like me and you weren't really enjoying the game much at this point, it can be a reason to feel like you're not getting anywhere and it won't make you want to play further. And that leads me to why this game is not for me. It has a lot of what I like in idlers but it lacks a certain charm or pull that makes it interesting for me or makes me want to invest time into learning its systems in more depth. Again, this is just personal taste. From an objective view, this idler is great. Maybe a quirky story could make it more interesting but I don't think it's necessary for its target audience.

My final thoughts is to give this game a go if you like idle games. If this game appeals to you and pulls you in, I believe you'll have a very rewarding time. It's just not for me.

EDIT for Dev: Don't stress about my review. As I said, I don't really think a story or that extra charm is necessary since what you already have here is good and it works for your target audience.

There's a lot that can be appreciated about this.  Also, I understand that at certain points these idle games radically change by adding new systems or asking you to "reincarnate" or whatever the system is called, but there's three main phases of the game:  Standard, Capital, and Fleet.  Standard is, in a word, great.  You swap between empowering various systems to inch your way forward as you would in a standard idle game.

Capital is insufferable and I honestly wanted to drop the game the moment it began.  I took several very long breaks over the course of capital.  Each new reset in capital (there's 5) was worse than the last.  You'd think gaining new passive would've made it better but it honestly just made it worse and worse.  I think it had to do with the knowledge that I'd lose everything and not actually gain anything aside from some artificial ladder rung while suffering waiting to see what fleet would have in store.

Fleet is...  definitely a choice in game design.  It's like starting out fresh in a Vampire Survivors type game.  You know you're going to be weak, but then you realize you have to wait 3.5 HOURS for each new attempt.  Each new tiny push into a hope of extra power.  I reached the second galaxy and gave up because it was just so completely and utterly boring.  Less a matter of waiting and micromanagement and more an exercise of just how much more we'll let this program string us along.  Like a mobile gacha game roping us in then revealing slowly just how little it respects the players and their time.

It's bad because if you're like me and you weren't really enjoying the game much at this point, it can be a reason to feel like you're not getting anywhere and it won't make you want to play further. And that leads me to why this game is not for me. It has a lot of what I like in idlers but it lacks a certain charm or pull that makes it interesting for me or makes me want to invest time into learning its systems in more depth. Again, this is just personal taste. From an objective view, this idler is great. Maybe a quirky story could make it more interesting but I don't think it's necessary for its target audience.

My final thoughts is to give this game a go if you like idle games. If this game appeals to you and pulls you in, I believe you'll have a very rewarding time. It's just not for me.

EDIT for Dev: Don't stress about my review. As I said, I don't really think a story or that extra charm is necessary since what you already have here is good and it works for your target audience.

There's a lot that can be appreciated about this.  Also, I understand that at certain points these idle games radically change by adding new systems or asking you to "reincarnate" or whatever the system is called, but there's three main phases of the game:  Standard, Capital, and Fleet.  Standard is, in a word, great.  You swap between empowering various systems to inch your way forward as you would in a standard idle game.

Capital is insufferable and I honestly wanted to drop the game the moment it began.  I took several very long breaks over the course of capital.  Each new reset in capital (there's 5) was worse than the last.  You'd think gaining new passive would've made it better but it honestly just made it worse and worse.  I think it had to do with the knowledge that I'd lose everything and not actually gain anything aside from some artificial ladder rung while suffering waiting to see what fleet would have in store.

Fleet is...  definitely a choice in game design.  It's like starting out fresh in a Vampire Survivors type game.  You know you're going to be weak, but then you realize you have to wait 3.5 HOURS for each new attempt.  Each new tiny push into a hope of extra power.  I reached the second galaxy and gave up because it was just so completely and utterly boring.  Less a matter of waiting and micromanagement and more an exercise of just how much more we'll let this program string us along.  Like a mobile gacha game roping us in then revealing slowly just how little it respects the players and their time.

Starts off with decent progression but as more features unlock, the balance breaks. All the game ends up being is finding which combination of upgrades will allow you to increase one stat the most, and then resetting each time you want to max a different stat, You HAVE to select extremely specific upgrades, crew, void devices, etc. to have any chance to progress. The problem is that each upgrade multiplies a stat by 10x-100x and the game requires that you hit certain breakpoints to be able to progress, meaning you basically have to get everything exact or you are simply wasting your time.

As far as idle games go, this one was pretty good at the start.  It has expanded over time with new achievements and game systems, but none of them have improved the enjoyment of the game.  It's just become a considerably longer, more grindy, idle game.  Can't recommend unless you are looking for something you can log into daily for the next several years to clear... if there isn't another patch.

Personally, I got a little overwhelmed with the complexity of certain aspects by the 5th area. I feel like there is too much faffing about to be enjoyable, even for an idle game. I prefer my games very simple, without too many separate upgrade functions. But it might suit those who enjoy that sort of thing. It's just not for me.

Upon learning a little more about the game from other reviews, it seems to be intended that you need to build your ship(s) a specific way to progress past certain points. That also doesn't appeal to me. I just like to wing it and leave things running until I get bored and uninstall.

Still, if that's your vibe then you'll love this.

Launching the game every 4 days to spend resources and immediately close the game is... not gameplay lol. I get that it's an idle game but going weeks without anything resembling progress is taking things a little too far.
